Comments_List:
I worked on my ability to make approximate calculations using informed estimates. Professor Prober would frequently pause to pose hypothetical quantitative questions, causing us to think critically about the assumptions we have to make to arrive at a figure.

Being a hybrid of a science course and a policy course, Prober's main lesson was to "ask the right questions" based on our observations. Throughout the semester, in scientific and nonscientific contexts, he showed us how people made history by asking the right questions.
I worked on my investigative skills, research abilities, and critical thinking.
I learned an interesting array of different modern tech around the world. Not much on public policy though.

I learned about various different technologies that I use on a daily basis but unfortunately knew nothing about. I think the information we discussed in class will make me a generally more informed person.

I think the main takeaway of the course (to ask the right questions) is salient to students in all disciplines. In my opinion, this takeaway represents the very best that a scientific mindset can contribute to non-science students. Bearing an SC distributional designation and being "not intended for science majors," this class does everything it promises and more. This class shows exactly why we need, and how students can benefit from, the SC distributional requirement.

Strengths: breadth of course, guest speakers 
Weakness: lecture format
It was a lot of lectures and not much about being a seminar. If we talked about the policy part a little more, there would be a lot more conversation back and forth

We covered many different interesting topics and had some amazing guest lecturers (including the VP of IBM Watson!). However, I wish we had more back-and-forth discussion because the class did not feel like a seminar. It was really just a small lecture.

The course ended up seeming a little more like a lecture than a seminar.  I really enjoyed the amazing guest speakers and lunches/dinners.  More class discussions in a conversational manner could potentially improve the class.  Nils is awesome too.  He helped a ton with going over questions that we had from the p-sets.
Yes, I would recommend this course to a student that is not a science major but is curious about various science technologies and how they work.
Yes, I would recommend and enjoyed the class.
Its a fun and relatively easy course to take and very interesting

I would recommend this course to a student who is really interested in physics and understanding technology. The course does not cover much public policy so be prepared to spend the majority of the time discussing physics.
Yes, but not every student.  If someone was interested in current scientific topics and issues, I would say it's a great and interesting course.
